Description: Transcription factor NRF2 is crucial for coordinated induction of cellular defense enzymes against oxidative and electrophilic stresses.  KEAP1 acts as a sensor for these stresses and also acts as a subunit of ubiquitin-E3 ligase that degrades NRF2 constitutively.  Genetic as well as pharmacological induction of NRF2 protect tissues from oxidative and electrophilic injury.  Meanwhile, many somatic missense mutations have been identified in KEAP1 and NRF2 genes of human cancers.  These mutations disrupt the KEAP1-NRF2 complex and result in constitutive activation of NRF2, which confers advantages on the cancer cell growth through the metabolic reprogramming and induction of cellular defense enzyme.  Research on the KEAP1-NRF2 system are expanding, including NRF2 regulation of inflammation, metabolism, aging, and neuroprotection.  Historical overview of the KEAP1-NRF2 system as well as recent progress of the pathway research in cancer biology and medicine will be discussed.
SearchResultBody: ME31. The KEAP1-NRF2 System in Cancer Biology and Medicine
Title: The KEAP1-NRF2 System in Cancer Biology and Medicine
